keyTakeAways: A fire broke out at Hungary’s Danube Refinery in Százhalombatta on Monday night, with no injuries reported.
The blaze occurred in a processing unit at the country’s only major crude-processing facility, which primarily processes Russian oil.
Hungary has maintained and even increased its imports of Russian oil despite EU-wide efforts to cut off such imports post-2022.
The fire has not disrupted domestic fuel supplies, as Prime Minister Viktor Orbán confirmed that Hungary’s fuel supply remains secure.
MOL, the national energy company, followed emergency protocols, restarted unaffected units, and is assessing whether to draw on strategic reserves.
Air quality around the site is being continuously monitored, and no health-limit violations have been detected.
The cause of the fire is under investigation, with emergency response led by the facility’s own fire brigade and supported by professional firefighters from nearby cities.
Eyewitnesses reported visible flames and smoke from several kilometers away, indicating the severity of the incident.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fire broke out at Hungary’s Danube Refinery in Százhalombatta on Monday night, with no injuries reported. The incident occurred at the country’s only major crude-processing facility, which primarily processes Russian oil, despite the EU’s efforts to cut off such imports since 2022. Hungary has maintained and even increased its Russian oil imports, highlighting its divergence from broader EU energy policy. Emergency response was swift, with the facility’s own fire brigade and professional firefighters from nearby areas arriving. MOL, the national energy company, confirmed that fuel supplies remain secure, and emergency protocols were followed. Air quality monitoring has detected no health risks, and the cause of the fire is under investigation. The event underscores Hungary’s strategic energy reliance on Russia in a continent-wide energy transition.
title: Fire at Hungary’s Main Oil Refinery Sparks Investigation Amid EU Energy Transition
